awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Actively Controllable Microfluidics with Film-Confined Redox-Magnetohydrodynamics: experiment and simulation
awd_abstract_narration:
Fritch/Isaac
1336853/1336722

Selective activation of redox-polymer-modified electrodes in a small volume in magnetic fields will be investigated to control microfluidics spatially and temporally. This new form of magnetohydrodynamics (MHD), as opposed to adding redox species to the solution or not adding them at all, defeats problems that hinder MHD from use in lab-on-a-chip (LOAC) devices. It allows higher currents with lower voltages, and thus, higher MHD forces and faster velocities without bubble formation or corrosion, faster response times, and compatibility with detectors and samples. MHD offers greater versatility over other micropumps, because flow can be programmed without redesigning channels of a device. An interdisciplinary, preexisting collaboration of investigators in Chemistry & Biochemistry at the Univ. of Arkansas and in Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering at Missouri Univ. of Science & Technology will perform the research.

Intellectual Merit :
Reduction/oxidation of chemical species confined to polymer films on electrodes creates an ionic current in solution. When at right angles to the magnetic field, the resulting MHD force causes fluid to flow there in the third dimension. Individually-addressable electrodes will be fabricated in desired patterns, polymer films will be polymerized and characterized by electrochemistry, electrodes will be activated with current and voltage in magnetic fields, and flow will be monitored by microbead movement in solution. The objectives are to (1) establish large coulombic capacity, fast response, and equivalent circuit models for redox-polymer films on electrodes, (2) control and maximize flow velocities, tune profiles, switch direction, and drive adjacent counter-flows using concentric disk-ring configurations of redox-polymer-modified electrodes perpendicular to a magnetic field, (3) sustain fluid flow by recharging redox-polymer films, and (4) use simulations to obtain spatial maps of ionic current density, MHD force density, and fluid velocities as a function of time, compare with experiment, and evaluate parameters that exceed experimental limits to better design redox-MHD microfluidic devices.

Broader Impacts :
The goal is to control microfluidics in a programmable way with far-reaching consequences toward products of interest to the public, such as hand-held, self-contained chemical analysis units for medical, environmental, and household uses. The interdisciplinary nature of the project enhances training of students involved in the research. Completed software modules will become available for testing and further evaluation to the scientific community free of charge.  An outreach collaboration between science, math, and language arts teachers at The New School and mentors at the U of A and Missouri S&T will use MHD as a starting point to stimulate viral learning for middle school students on topics of forces and energy. Students will perform self-directed projects in collaboration with teachers and mentors, communicate results with videos using their own vocabulary and perspective, which they have scripted, edited, produced, and post them on the internet for public viewing and commentary. This approach is expected to bridge the gap between university research and middle school education, while simultaneously enhancing STEM education and educator development and increasing public scientific literacy and public engagement with science and technology.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.inst_name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

perf_inst.perf_inst_name: Missouri University of Science and Technology

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Selective activation of redox-polymer-modified electrodes in a small volume in magnetic fields was investigated to control microfluidics spatially and temporally. This new form of magnetohydrodynamics (MHD), as opposed to adding redox species to the solution or not adding them at all, addresses problems that hinder using MHD in lab-on-a-chip (LOAC) devices. It allows higher currents with lower voltages, and thus, higher MHD forces and faster velocities without bubble formation or corrosion, faster response times, and compatibility with detectors and samples. MHD offers greater versatility over other micropumps, because flow can be programmed without redesigning channels of a device. An interdisciplinary collaboration of investigators in Mechanical & Aerospace Engineering at Missouri Univ. of Science & Technology, and Chemistry & Biochemistry at the Univ. of Arkansas performed the research. Reduction/oxidation of chemical species confined to polymer films on electrodes creates an ionic current in solution. When the current flux vector is perpendicular to the magnetic field vector, the resulting MHD force perpendicular to both, causes fluid to flow in the direction of the force. Individually-addressable electrodes were fabricated in desired patterns, polymer films were polymerized and characterized by electrochemistry, electrodes were activated with current and voltage in magnetic fields, and flow was monitored by microbead movement in solution. In this project with emphasis on developing mathematical models and performing computer simulations, the objectives were to (1) establish large coulombic capacity, fast response, and equivalent circuit models for redox-polymer films on electrodes, (2) control and maximize flow velocities, tune profiles, switch direction, and drive adjacent counter-vortices using concentric disk-ring configurations of redox-polymer-modified electrodes perpendicular to a magnetic field, (3) sustain fluid flow by recharging redox-polymer films, and (4) obtain spatial maps of ionic current density, MHD force density, and fluid velocities as a function of time, compare with experiment, and evaluate parameters that lie beyond experimental limits to better design redox-MHD microfluidic devices. The CFD simulations enabled the creation of a large library of simulation results that will be useful for researchers in microfluidics.

The project advanced knowledge in several ways. Successful completion enabled a paradigm shift in microfluidic control of multiple functions on LOAC devices. Redox-polymer films were created with high coulombic capacity for repeatable MHD microfluidic control in many electrolytes and buffers. Fundamental knowledge of relationships between fluid velocity, electrode dimensions, ionic current density, and magnetic field intensity, expressed in terms of non-dimensional parameters, led to optimized device designs and identification of suitable applications that may included stopping, varying velocity and profile, direction switching, mixing, tailoring localized flow around objects, and splitting fluid for further differential processing. Strategies were also developed to sustain fluid flow over long time periods. The simulations guided interpretation of the interplay of factors on flow and predict values for non-dimensional parameters needed to achieve desired microfluidic behavior that was not previously achievable, thereby driving future research.

The developed pumping approach will be able to control microfluidics in a programmable way with far-reaching consequences toward products of interest to the public, such as hand-held, self-contained chemical analysis units for medical, environmental, and household uses. The interdisciplinary nature of the project enhances training of students involved in the research.

An added outcome of the project that went beyond the scope of the proposed research was the development of a mathematical model for natural convection arising from redox electrochemical reactions under isothermal conditions. The results from the simulations were compared with experiments and Missouri S&T with good agreement between the simulations and the experiments. This new natural convection model could explain some of the unexplained behavior in redox electrochemistry experiments.

An outreach collaboration between science, math, and language arts teachers at The New School and mentors used MHD as a starting point to stimulate viral learning for middle school students on topics of fluid dynamics and energy. The students were introduced to fundamental fluid dynamics principles such as force equilibrium, stability, pressure variation and drag, with the help of a video created and Missouri S&T, on the up-and-down and sideways motion of a ball suspended in an air stream.  Students performed self-directed projects in collaboration with teachers and mentors, communicated results with videos using their own vocabulary and perspective, which they scripted, produced, edited. They posted the videos on the web for public viewing and commentary. This approach is expected to bridge the gap between university research and middle school education, while simultaneously enhancing STEM education and educator development and increasing public scientific literacy and public engagement with science and technology.

  

 


Last Modified: 03/29/2018
Modified by: Kakkattukuzhy M Isaac
